author: m.kalinin
content: This is reasonable question. Suppose, EL moves to a separate shard, an execution payload will contain the root of a beacon block it's built upon. Which already implies some dependency, even minimal, but it seems unavoidable. And verifying this root implies running a beacon chain node, potentially a light client node. And we might want to avoid dependencies going beyond the light client -- this sounds like a reasonable boundary for how far we want to go with tying two layers.

I like this. The work for people who are worried would be to propose a mechanism that allows them to verify they are legit, maybe by showing control of the deposit wallet. And then the dot txt could be restricting the 00->01 change to just the eoa of the deposit wallet.
Someone who lost control of both deposit wallet and validator mnemonic, I don’t know a reasonable way to prove ownership.

author: pietjepuk
content:
> The work for people who are worried would be to propose a mechanism that allows them to verify they are legit, maybe by showing control of the deposit wallet. And then the dot txt could be restricting the 00->01 change to just the eoa of the deposit wallet.
Hmm, this is sort of the opposite direction of my original thinking. You're saying to set up a website where people can submit "I own pubkey X, deposit address Y, and this is the tx hash of my deposit" messages? I'd like to avoid a central website if at all possible, but it's going to be hard to make a single txt/json out of these messages otherwise. And also everyone that runs the file should still check with their EL client that the tx is correct.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I am not in private contact with any no, but you can see from the links I posted they exist. Many I assume are just not sure if they lost sole-ownership, not necessarily that they _know_ they did. So I'm mostly just trying to work out what a possible solution would look like that they could center around. My thinking was a little different to yours though:

1a) There is a period of time where 0x00 -> 0x01 messages are being accepted by CL clients, but before they can be included on-chain and/or
1b) There is a (low) limit to the number of 0x00 -> 0x01 credential switches in a block.
2) CL client have to rebroadcast **and store/cache** (important assumption!) these messages for later inclusion.
3) CL clients have to do _something_ locally when multiple competing message arrive  (even it is just "pick the last one" or "ignore all but the first")
4) Have a json map/dict of _all_ pubkey -> deposit addresses, and then the CL client can have an eviction strategy like "overwrite unless existing messages matches json file"

The latter can be generated by a script that everyone can run against their own EL client.

author: pietjepuk
content: The biggest challenges I see is that this all has to work _before_ credential changes are accepted on the beacon chain, and that node operators have to be convinced to use the option (because it's opt-in). Especially the latter might deter those affected from trying to tackle the first challenge.
